Text.val: This is where the Merge is called
Call Notepad to view or edit the template
You can change this to call the editor of your choice.
This relies on the the Windows associations to choose the right program
for viewing the data. You can specifically name the program to use if you want.

Text.valUnicode: {\rtf1\ansi\ansicpg1252\deff0\deflang1033{\fonttbl{\f0\fnil\fcharset0 Microsoft Sans Serif;}{\f1\fswiss\fprq2\fcharset0 Microsoft Sans Serif;}} {\colortbl ;\red0\green0\blue0;\red255\green0\blue128;} {\*\generator Msftedit 5.41.15.1515;}\viewkind4\uc1\pard\cf1\b\f0\fs20 The Magic Merge feature is a convenient way to combine database information with text, HTML, XML, or Excel. \par \par The Magic Merge works on a few basic principles:\par \par 1. The \cf2 Template\cf1 is a text file which contains the\cf2 formatting\cf1 for the desired output file.\par 2. The Magic\cf2 program\cf1 handles the \cf2 data\cf1 that will be merged into that output.\par 3. A series of \cf2 Tags\cf1 are used to link the two. Tags are simply text strings that follow a specific format, which by default is:\par \par \cf2 <!$MG_\cf1\b0\i\f1 Tag name\cf2\b\i0\f0 >\cf1\par \par What this means is that different templates can be used with the same program, or vice versa. It means that a qualified end-user can edit the templates, without altering the program at all.\par \par It is often useful to have a generic program that will output data based on some filtering range given at runtime by the user, and to allow the user to use a series of templates (or create their own) according to what kind of output they want. This example uses that approach. For the sake of simplicity, no "filtering" screen is provided, but the ranging would work as it does in any other Magic program.\par }

ExpSyntax.val: 'MG01_How Do I Merge Data into a Text File? '

Comment.val:
The "Report" in this case is just a text file. The file name is specified in the Exp/Var column.
Because the Access is Write, the existing file will be overlaid.
If more than one Merge program needs to be used, the I/O Name to use property can be used to link the two programs together.

Text.val: This is the Data View used to create the Merged output
Any combination of Ranges, Locates, Linked Records, and Virtuals may be used here.
In addition, the Tag table supports Expressions, so data can be calculated or modified at runtime.
This example does not use a Range, so all the records in the table will be merged.
This is a misc. text line that is used for commenting, in this example.
Each record that has tags inside the MGREPEAT block will repeat, as if it were in a table.
The Tag table makes the connection between the variables in the Data View and the tags in
Different templates can be used, as long as the same tags are used.
See the comments (F12) on the Merge Template form for more details.
There are also comments on the I/O Device

_Comment.valUnicode:
This is the Merge Template. It basically creates a link between the tags in the template and the variables in the Data View.
In this case, the Template is chosen at runtime. You can see the Expression that specifies it in the File name property.
However, a specific template is also hard-coded in the File name property. This hard-coded name is used to help create the Tags table. Also, the specific template can be edited from this form, by zooming from the Form name ("Merge Template").

ExpSyntax.val: 'This was printed by: ' & User(0) & ' on ' & DStr(Date(),'##/##/####')
